title: Balance transfer checks & Chapter 7 Bankruptcy? How do I "fix" this without ruining my chance to file for bankruptcy?
question: My husband & I had approx 38K in credit card debt, recently we asked my parents for a personal loan of 17K. Right away I payed off a card & also payed a couple others down significantly. Two weeks later my parents had unexpected repairs on home & needed $9,000 of the loan back. I tried calling the credit companies to reverse the payments but it was too late. I then had to resort to a couple cards we had that offered balance transfers & had one send a $4,000 check & another a check for $5,000 (one in my name & one in my husbands name). Getting nowhere with debt we'd been trying to pay off for 8 years now, we did some research on bankruptcy & found out about "insider" loans, preferences & time frames for balance transfers,etc! I still have checks, what should my next step be???
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Credit,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
Have you repaid any of the loans from your parents yet? You don't state it, but if you did within 12 months prior to filing your bankruptcy case, it is a recoverable transfer. You can't really un-ring the bell on that one without there being other consequences.

As for the recent balance transfer, also a problem, but may be explainable depending on the overall pattern of usage on the cards. You would need to have a qualifed bankruptcy attorney evaluate everything and examine your options. Most likely the wise thing to do, unless there are pressing reasons not to, would be to wait a year to file your bankruptcy case and not incur any new debt in the interim.

This has potential of being a huge mess for your family.

This is not an internet question.

Get into an attorney's office.

Don't do anything else and stop any payments if possible.

Good luck.

Your next step should be into the office of an experienced bankruptcy lawyer. Your options are limited and the consquences of a bad move are too great to chance it here. As knowledgable and caring as are the Avvo attorneys, you really need a full case review, not just "advice" based on the limited facts you have disclosed.

If you do not know an experienced bankruptcy lawyer (and your issues call for the most adept of practitioners), use the attorney-finder at www.nacba.org. I am a longtime proud member of NACBA, and trust my CA colleagues to advise accurately and protect clients aggressively.

Best wishes for a favorable outcome, and please remember to designate a best answer.
